response.answer_text: 33+8 collapsed = 41 answers, and nobody pointed out the pink elephant in the room. So, here goes. The black holes, white holes, worm holes, stuff is bogus. Not every physicist realizes this yet, so, please be aware that what I am going to say is not totally accepted yet. But, it is not just my perspective, either. It is a growing perspective within the physics community. There are many ways to go about dealing with this, but since everyone here is raving about Kip Thorne’s book allegedly proving the physics is correct, let us use his best work on the subject:  Kip Thorne’s decision to call it exotic matter is illustrative of the sort of mentality he has. He is implying there is “matter” with negative energy. As an example he implies that the Casimir effect proves that negative energy exists between two conductive plates.. While it is true that many physicists thought that the 1948 paper by Casimir and Polder proved the existence of vacuum energies pressure me use that bible itself to show the problem. Here, in his beloved book he describes someone like the protagonist Joseph Cooper entering the black hole in the movie:  Let’s just read the green underlined text. Consider Murphy. She is Cooper’s daughter, left back on doomed planet Earth. Based on the above text, and really any knowledge of black holes, from her perspective, before Cooper enters any black hole, she has to experience an infinite amount of time just for Cooper to get to the event horizon, let alone get past it. The point is that before Cooper gets to the event horizon, his daughter is dead of old age. The Sun explodes too. For sure, Cooper can’t come back out of it and see his daughter alive, since she already died before he even entered the black hole. It takes eternity just to get to the edge. I guess the problem within the black hole physics community was that they for some reason have an issue with realizing that Einstein was wrong. He wrote that all reference frames are OK to solve problems in. The problem with this is that other reference frames do exist. Specifically, our universe does exist. And so does everything in it. If you use another reference frame, namely Kruskal–Szekeres coordinates that has our time going past infinity in it, as Misner and Thorne explained in their book which I read in junior high school, you aren’t doing anything related to our actual universe anymore. It is just wrong. At best, it is fantasy. That’s the problem with classical black hole physics. And, the error is made very clear by this movie and the fact that it was blessed by a so-called GR physics God that everyone else is either too mentally weak to see as wrong or is just too afraid to expose. Anyway, this is why there cannot even be singularities in the first place. They would take forever to form. There are just these black hole-like objects. It’s a technical question if they should be called black holes or not, but real physicists who do GR simulations of their formation will agree that they are largely frozen in time with smooth mass density functions; there is no infinite density as viewed in our reference frame, and assuming our universe exists, there’s no way to form a singularity. Kip’s papers and books are wrong. To summarize, if you think physicists like Kip are right about black holes, then OK, this aspect of the physics is correct for you. But, historically speaking, sometimes physicists have disagreed. And, good physics are unsure of many things. And, sometimes they change their minds, and think they were wrong. In this case, I think Kip is wrong, but so is a growing sector of the physics community, too. I attempted to published this result back in 1983, but the paper was rejected. Since then, other physicists have published similar papers, but there is a lot of politics on this hot potato, so it may take time. Some get it. Some don’t. To me, it is plain as day, and I think anyone intelligent who reads this post objectively will understand. One thing I was very happy about was that Kip didn’t lie about the past. Their views have not been altered changed. (When confronted about the time dilation issues, some other physicists I spoke with would try to downplay and rationalize things by claiming, “Well, you’re right, but everyone knows this doesn’t really happen that way, etc.”) The movie solidifies the problems with black hole physics, and hopefully it will help speed up the rate at which people realize that most popular views of black hole physics are wrong. At the very least, physicists can use the movie to make their points, just as I did here. That’s just the problem with the black hole. The movie is actually largely based upon a worm hole, which is different. The worm hole as idealized has a different problem. To construct the worm hole used in the movie, there would need to be something Kip and others call exotic matter. It is matter with a negative mass. Many physics, me included, do not thing exotic matter can ever exist. Kip and other “pro worm hole” physicists have written several papers the primary purpose of which is to argue in favor of exotic matter being possible. However, many physicists, me included, view these papers as mere hand waving arguments, not rigorous proofs of anything substantive. Thus far, matter having a negative mass has never been observed in any laboratory. In my own opinion, worm holes cannot ever be constructed, and I’m not alone in my opinion. I missed much of the movie, so I won’t comment on too many other physics issues with it. It is just too old, and there are already other answers here addressing many of the other errors. But, a few of the more glaring potential issues: NASA scientists are not backstabbing jerks. Sorry, the fight in the movie is unlikely to happen. Sorry this isn’t a physics issue. It is more of a science issue. The tides. You’d get tidal locking in no time, and it would be dry or wet, not shallow and then super deep. As I wrote, I missed the first part of the movie but I didn’t get why some equation solution encoded in Morse code saves Earth. It is tempting to point out that fixing whatever environmental issues we have is much easier and more energy efficient than moving light years away, so the core plot is also probably unlikely for this reason. But, I don’t mind this since that’s what allows lots of good SF, and of course there are reasons to go out there regardless. If Cooper can move the watch second hand, he can directly interact too. So, he can just encode a computer text file, which takes less force, or probably even pick up a pen and write it all out. Whatever it is. (I didn’t see him deriving equations, so where is he getting anything?) Then again, I think his daughter would have been dead and he could never get into the worm hole let alone out, so I guess I will stop here. Despite all this I thought it was a good movie for Hollywood, albeit a little dark. Upvote, follow, and share to spread the word!
